thread.title: Football: Clifton High School falls to Ridgewood 30-14
thread.title_full: Football: Clifton High School falls to Ridgewood 30-14

title: Football: Clifton High School falls to Ridgewood 30-14
text:
For three straight weeks, the Clifton football team had played good football. 
The Mustangs' efforts were strong, and at full speed. 
But for about a quarter-and-a-half Friday night, Clifton failed to execute, getting beat up front and committing uncharacteristic mistakes. 
The slow start would prove fatal to their hopes of remaining undefeated, as they fell to the always fundamentally sound Ridgewood Maroons, 30-14, at Ridgewood High School. 
"We didn't show up the first 18 minutes of the game," said Clifton head coach Ralph Cinque, who suffered his first defeat as the Mustangs' leader. 
"They put 24 on us in the first 18 minutes. You can't spot any team 18 points, let alone Ridgewood. That's a great football team." 
It wasn't that the Mustangs (2-1-1) didn't have their early chances, though. 
After a Maroons field goal, Clifton scored a fumble recovery that put it well into Ridgewood territory. 
But Jack Kiernan picked off Clifton quarterback Joe Santillo just one play later, killing any chance for the Mustangs to build momentum-or generate points. 
The Maroons also maintained a noticeable advantage at the line of scrimmage, using disciplined blocking schemes to execute their Wing-T offense to near-perfection. 
It was easily the most difficult night of the year for the Clifton front four, which had been outstanding in its first three games. 
"The offense Ridgewood runs is about angles," Cinque noted. 
"Defensively, I think our line was coming upfield too much, creating some gaps. I think our kids had a learning experience Friday night, and I know they are going to work hard this week to get better." 
A blackout in the second half failed to stymie Ridgewood's groove, and the Maroons (4-1) led by 30 before Santillo and wide receiver Delano Dixon hooked up for two touchdowns in the fourth. 
The loss makes Clifton's matchup with struggling Kennedy one of greater consequence. 
A loss would be devastating to Clifton's playoff hopes. 
The Mustangs currently sit in sixth place in the North 1, Group 5 power point standings, according to GridironNewJersey.com. 
"This will be most important game of the year because it is the only one we are playing," Cinque said of the showdown with the Knights. "It's definitely a must-win. If we have any hopes of making the playoffs and playing into November, we have to win Friday." 
The Mustangs host Kennedy tonight at 7 p.m. Â© 2015 North Jersey Media Group Tags:
